definitions.definition: To catch or tear (e.g. fabric) upon a rough surface or projection.
examples: Be careful not to snag your stockings on that concrete bench!

definitions.definition: To damage or sink (a vessel) by collision; said of a tree or branch fixed to the bottom of a navigable body of water and partially submerged or rising to just beneath the surface.
examples: The steamboat was snagged on the Mississippi River in 1862.

definitions.definition: To fish by means of dragging a large hook or hooks on a line , intending to impale the body (rather than the mouth) of the target.
examples: We snagged for spoonbill from the eastern shore of the Mississippi River.

definitions.definition: To obtain or pick up , especially in a quick or surreptitious way.
examples: Ella snagged a bottle of water from the fridge before leaving for her jog.

definitions.definition: To cut the snags or branches from, as the stem of a tree; to hew roughly.

main_definition: To catch or tear (e.g. fabric) upon a rough surface or projection.
secondary_definitions: To damage or sink (a vessel) by collision; said of a tree or branch fixed to the bottom of a navigable body of water and partially submerged or rising to just beneath the surface.
( fishing ) To fish by means of dragging a large hook or hooks on a line , intending to impale the body (rather than the mouth) of the target.
( slang , transitive ) To obtain or pick up , especially in a quick or surreptitious way.
( UK , dialect ) To cut the snags or branches from, as the stem of a tree; to hew roughly.
( slang , Native American ) To have noncommittal sexual relations.
